posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

>>14360812
>In russia (granted, I'm sure there are plenty of russians who really fucking hate stalin and the communists) some look at stalin as good for keeping the germans from exterminating the russians
Oh yeah he definitely has his haters in Russia too. But yeah that, and he's like Napoleon really. He was a bad guy who murdered people and destroyed nations, but he also laid the foundations for the modern Russian state (which does bear its markings even though it's no longer "communist") and spread his ideals beyond his country's borders where they still persist in a form in China. The CPSU itself also outlasted him.

Hitler was just a counter-revolutionary and his regime was totally destroyed. Stalin was more complex because he was a revolutionary but also one that reversed some of it in a half-conservative way like Napoleon did who crowned himself emperor. I buy the theory that Stalinism was a weird paradox of an ideology because it was Marxism adapting itself to a society that had barely emerged from feudalism, so the Communist Party accelerated and powered that society into industrialization, but it adopted an "Asiatic" (ehh) or "magical" superstructure much like a pre-capitalist civilization with Stalin rendered much like Akhenaten or an ancient Sun God. That allowed it to hold together during this process in the 1930s-1940s.

Most normies today would recoil in disgust at this regime, and there are parts of it that do read like a horror novel. But I think it "made sense" (logically, if not "rationally") for such a society undergoing such a transition at that time, and its own success -- industrialization and the entrance into modernity -- rendered it obsolete.

One problem ideologically is that if you're used to treating Stalin as a demigod, then there's a big crisis when he dies, so I think modern-day "Stalinists" are kinda like the equivalent of a cargo cult in Ancient Egypt that went around proclaiming Akhenaten as their God decades after he died.

>>14361548
There is a written tradition, going back to the early sixth century, that says the first Anglo-Saxons in Britain were mercenaries who mutinied against their British employers and began seizing the island by force. The archaeology seems to say something quite different. The earliest Saxon cemeteries, dating to the mid fifth century and found in the Thames Valley and Essex, seem to be of ordinary farmers. These are poor people, buried without weapons. Their settlements are undefended, and they seem to have existed side-by-side with equally undefended settlements of ordinary Romano-British farmers. There is also considerable evidence for contact between the two peoples: hundreds of British place names survived, the genetics seems to show substantial intermarriage, many old community boundaries were maintained. The culture we call Anglo-Saxon seems to have emerged gradually from the mixing of British and barbarian elements, and not until nearly a century later do we have much evidence for Anglo-Saxon warriors, especially warrior aristocrats

There's very little Gaulish influence on French too, which is kind of shocking considering the Frankish influence on French.
The conclusions we can draw are that Celtic languages probably weren't particularly different from either Germanic or Italic languages, particularly in these earlier stages.

The further back you go the more similar all these languages become until they are just the same language, Proto-Indo-European.
They hadn't really been separate languages for such a long time before they began colliding together again and they probably still remained in a language contact zone through trade and other interactions.

There's also the very realistic scenario that regions that were ruled by Celtic elites and dynasties may well not have been Celtic-speaking among the common population which may have consisted largely of slaves and conquered peoples from other ethnolinguistic groups.

The division between North Spain and South Spain.

Baeticans (andalucians) before Al-Aldanlus (Tartessos) era received mass influences from eastern mediterranean (phoenicians and greeks) and where colonized by punics first, and romans later. When Arabs arrived from the eastern end of the world back then, although they conquered a good part of the peninsula at first, before the reconquest they only dedicated themselves to maintaining the territories of the old provinces of Tarraconensis and especially Baetica. During the climax of power in Al-Andalus; the warlord Almanzor led successful campaigns against the Kingdom of Leon, the Basque clans and the Catalan counties, but he never annexed them to Al-Andalus but kept them as tributary states. A similar case occurred before the push of the North African empires such as the Almohads, Almoravids and Marinid, the main objective was not so much to conquer but to maintain Andalusia and Valencia.

Not ironically, the Muslim caliphates were the heirs of the silent ancient Mediterranean, they were welcomed by the centers of civilization of the ancient world, such as Syria, Anatolia, Magna Graecia, Tartessos, Tunisia, Mesopotamia and Persia.

posts.com:
Hello,

After more than 20 years, I've finally decided to tell the world what I witnessed in 1991, which I believe was one of the biggest turning point in popular music, and ultimately American society. I have struggled for a long time weighing the pros and cons of making this story public as I was reluctant to implicate the individuals who were present that day. So I've simply decided to leave out names and all the details that may risk my personal well being and that of those who were, like me, dragged into something they weren't ready for.

Between the late 80's and early 90’s, I was what you may call a “decision maker” with one of the more established company in the music industry. I came from Europe in the early 80’s and quickly established myself in the business. The industry was different back then. Since technology and media weren’t accessible to people like they are today, the industry had more control over the public and had the means to influence them anyway it wanted. This may explain why in early 1991, I was invited to attend a closed door meeting with a small group of music business insiders to discuss rap music’s new direction. Little did I know that we would be asked to participate in one of the most unethical and destructive business practice I’ve ever seen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The meeting was held at a private residence on the outskirts of Los Angeles. I remember about 25 to 30 people being there, most of them familiar faces. Speaking to those I knew, we joked about the theme of the meeting as many of us did not care for rap music and failed to see the purpose of being invited to a private gathering to discuss its future. Among the attendees was a small group of unfamiliar faces who stayed to themselves and made no attempt to socialize beyond their circle. Based on their behavior and formal appearances, they didn't seem to be in our industry. Our casual chatter was interrupted when we were asked to sign a confidentiality agreement preventing us from publicly discussing the information presented during the meeting. Needless to say, this intrigued and in some cases disturbed many of us. The agreement was only a page long but very clear on the matter and consequences which stated that violating the terms would result in job termination. We asked several people what this meeting was about and the reason for such secrecy but couldn't find anyone who had answers for us. A few people refused to sign and walked out. No one stopped them. I was tempted to follow but curiosity got the best of me. A man who was part of the “unfamiliar” group collected the agreements from us.

posts.com: Quickly after the meeting began, one of my industry colleagues (who shall remain nameless like everyone else) thanked us for attending. He then gave the floor to a man who only introduced himself by first name and gave no further details about his personal background. I think he was the owner of the residence but it was never confirmed. He briefly praised all of us for the success we had achieved in our industry and congratulated us for being selected as part of this small group of “decision makers”. At this point I begin to feel slightly uncomfortable at the strangeness of this gathering. The subject quickly changed as the speaker went on to tell us that the respective companies we represented had invested in a very profitable industry which could become even more rewarding with our active involvement. He explained that the companies we work for had invested millions into the building of privately owned prisons and that our positions of influence in the music industry would actually impact the profitability of these investments. I remember many of us in the group immediately looking at each other in confusion. At the time, I didn’t know what a private prison was but I wasn't the only one. Sure enough, someone asked what these prisons were and what any of this had to do with us. We were told that these prisons were built by privately owned companies who received funding from the government based on the number of inmates. The more inmates, the more money the government would pay these prisons.

There is a pattern among some Marxists and Socialists to think of the bourgeois as having a merely parasitic function, making their money entirely from their employees labour without doing any work themselves. This "parasite" analysis only makes sense for rentiers (landlords etc.). It doesn't make sense for employers, who have to run the business (which is as real work as any) and take the risk of losing everything if the business fails.
Additionally, I think it is clear that most members of the working class prefer wage labour over having to manage a business and risk losing everything in the process. They prefer economic security over owning their labour, which is why working class activity was always exclusively union politics, aiming at class compromise and not class war (revolutionary politics).
Workers are not interested in Socialism. Professional revolutionaries like Lenin are

posts.com:
>>14365892
>What exactly IS degeneracy
Degeneracy is no single phenomenon or even a single concept, nor is it very well defined (and people will disagree on the definitions). The term obviously means something like decline, un-development, i.e. something is bad or becoming worse that used to be better. In that it differs from things that are still bad, but used to be just as bad or even worse. The concept is somewhat unpopular in modern culture, since we are used to the idea that things just somehow keep getting better - in terms of tech, standards of living, safety, etc. which is, of course, because it really was like that for a long time.
Now, what exactly is bad or not is subjective of course, and opinions on whether some things lead to good or bad things are subjective as well (even if people agree on what is good or bad). For example, people will universally agree that mental health is good. Many people will think that traditional families serve mental health, will others won't (no comment on what the science says on the matter). Conservatives will also say traditional families are good by themselves, which leftists will vehemently oppose.

>Fuck it bows and arrows in the back of the battlefield
Literally the reason why bow and arrows were dropped in favor of muskets was because the average peasant needed a lifetime of training to develop the muscle mass to draw a 100-lb bow and loose them repeatedly. Even then, they could do maybe 2-3 a minute and tiring out after 10-15 draws on top of straining their fingers. Peasants and yeomen can be rapidly trained to use a musket, with more devastating firepower, and for longer periods of time since it isn't as physically demanding.

Bows have less range, less consistent penetration power, and logistically it's more difficult to make and supply arrows than it is some lead balls and gunpowder (just keep it dry).

There's a reason why in virtually every battle, those with guns beat those without.

>>14363679
Rl21 is the closest clade to Ru152. Most likely they diverged in the Bronze Age in the context of the unetice culture expansion. Rl21 was primarily spread by earlier proto-celts-italic spread (before separation of Celtic and italic, possibly represented by Ligurian). Ru152 was spread by later celts and italics spreading from the eastern alps. Both groups contained mixed r1b but a population bottleneck in the British isles and Ireland caused rl21 to be over represented. Rl21 has a major presence in the eastern alps. It is the dominant haplotype in the area of Ortisei, being rather diffuse in rhaeto-romance peoples, as well as neighbouring Slovenian littoral, central Slovenia, Istria, and northern Croatia.

>Abdallah marched a force of 5,000 men to the Makurian capital of Dongola in 651.[1] He was equipped with heavy cavalry and a catapult (manjaniq), probably a traction trebuchet,[4] which according to al-Maqrizi the Makurians had never seen before.[3] He then laid siege to the city,[5] putting his cavalry in the precarious situation of storming a walled city defended by the infamous Nubian archers.[6] During the siege the town's cathedral was damaged by catapult fire.[1] (A damaged church has been discovered outside the remains of the city walls dating to the mid-seventh century.[3])

>The siege ended in a pitched battle.[7] The casualties incurred by Abdallah's forces were heavy,[6] and Qalidurut did not sue for peace.[1] In the end, Abdallah called off the siege and negotiated a pact (baqt).[2] According to the 9th-century Egyptian historian Ibn 'Abd al-Hakam this was because "he was unable to defeat them". The 10th-century Shiite historian Ahmad al-Kufi, who had no sympathy for the forces of the caliph, had an even stronger opinion: "The Muslims had never [before] suffered a loss like the one they had in Nubia."[7] An Arab poet describing the battle wrote:[8]

>"My eyes ne'er saw another fight like Damqula [Dongola],
With rushing horses loaded down with coats of mail."
In the centuries that followed, however, the siege and second battle of Dongola were transformed by Muslim historians into a victory. Qalidurut was said to have come out of the city submissively seeking terms, according to al-Maqrizi.[7] It may be that this version of events stems from the conflation of the events of 652 with late 13th-century conflict between Nubia and the Mamluks.[3]

Public support internationally for war crimes trials was practically dead by the mid 70's, with even the new york times calling it "dragging" in 1975. That's probably why they needed some new propaganda. It's quite possible that the Hollywood propaganda in 1978 got Germany to extend its statute of limitations to convict people as accessories to murder during WWII which ended in 1979, but I don't care enough to actually see if that's true.

>>14363119
In the run up to the war the Luftwaffe was built around the doctrine that they would be primarily focused on close support for the Wehrmacht, so they focused on attack aircraft and light/medium bombers. It's kind of hard to do strategic bombing with a Stuka, but their heavier medium bombers did more or less OK in that role, as British cities of the day can tell you.

In comparison the RAF spent most of the interwar years focused on building larger and longer ranged bombers, initially for use in 'colonial policing' (you don't need to worry about a colonial town objecting to regulations when you can send a half dozen heavy bombers loaded with incendiaries in to 'resolve the issue'). Which were much better suited to carpet bombing industrial and residential areas.

Ultimately the RAF did better to cover their weak point as the war went on, but German military procurement during WWII was the sort of clusterfuck-horror show that makes the worst jokes about corruption in the Pentagon look like a smoothly oiled machine.

An important question is how much ancestry modern Sardinians have inherited from people related to those of the Nuragic Bronze Age. We could parsimoniously model our modern Sardinian sample as a 2-way mixture of 13.6 ± 3.4% Sardinia_Nuragic_BA and 86.4 ± 3.4% Sardinia_LateAntiquity12221. It is striking that most of the ancestry in modern Sardinians is inferred in this analysis to come from a Sardinia_LateAntiquity12221-related group, which can itself be modeled as closely related to Mycenaeans or Phoenicians with no evidence of specific shared ancestry with Bronze Age Sardinians.

modern Sardinians harbor substantial fractions of ancestry from several groups that arrived in Europe after the Neolithic, and we model modern Sardinians as harboring 10.0 ± 1.6% Steppe ancestry and an even larger 19.1 ± 1.9% Iranian-related ancestry. Both ancestry types are definitively required to model modern Sardinians, and we show that modern Sardinians have been substantially impacted by movement of ancestry from North Africa in the last two millennia.

To test how much ancestry in modern Sardinians could be derived from local Sardinians from the Bronze Age and earlier, we examined the 27 modern Sardinians that have been the source of many of these previous estimates63, who are from the Gennargentu region and have among the least Steppe ancestry among modern Sardinians who vary in their ancestry proportions reflecting the geographic substructuring of modern Sardinians among different valleys and coastal and inland sites79. So, Murray’s method was to measure the amount of space dedicated to historical figures in various encyclopaedias. This raised my suspicion that Murray may have relied heavily on Western sources. And how do you account for cultures that have been stamped out? Take the Spanish and their burning of nearly all of the books of the Mayans. Much science and art have been lost in the time span from 800 B.C. to 1950.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14360839
It wasn't. There was a constant string of mass murders and war crimes committed by American troops throughout the entire decade of American involvement in the war.
Every major American unit in Vietnam, down to the brigade, had "incidents" wherein Vietnamese civilians were abused, murdered, and raped. The only thing exceptional about My Lai was its scope, killing hundreds at once was a step too far that couldn't be hidden. But the brutalization and killings of civilians was routine.
Even the most cursory examination of the evidence shows this, and it isn't even hidden or disputed. The US military's own analysis showed that during Operation Speedy Express, for example, 5000-7000 of the 10000 Vietnamese killed were civilians. The most outrageous stories there coming from the helicopter and light plane crews that admitted to military investigators that they constantly just murdered anyone they saw for any reason they could think of.
The ubiquitous search and destroy missions were much more up close and personal. Many times these were just covers for the wholesale destruction of a village that happened to be close to a place where a Viet Cong ambush had taken place, or where a GI had gotten injured or killed by a trap or mine. Troops bombed the village, rolled in, burned the houses, killed the livestock, raped the women, and then killed them along with anyone else they could get their hands on. I suggest you read Jamie Henry's account of one such attack. The highlight is really something, and it was attested to by multiple witnesses to military investigators. Or you could read about Roy Bumgarner, who was known as a murderer among troops and was convicted of manslaughter after gunning down four civilians and blowing their heads up with a grenade to teach some new recruits how to conduct themselves.
I can't do the extent of the violence justice, there is too much and I get too angry. I highly advise you look into this, what happened in Vietnam was pure evil.

>The program, which lasted from 1967 to 1972, was designed to identify and destroy the Viet Cong (VC) via infiltration, torture, capture, counter-terrorism, interrogation, and assassination. The CIA described it as "a set of programs that sought to attack and destroy the political infrastructure of the Viet Cong." The Phoenix Program was premised on the idea that North Vietnamese infiltration had required local support within noncombat civilian populations, which were referred to as the "VC infrastructure" and "political branch" that had purportedly coordinated the insurgency.

>Throughout the program, Phoenix "neutralized" 81,740 people suspected of VC membership, of whom 26,369 were killed, and the rest surrendered or were captured.

>The Phoenix Program was heavily criticized on various grounds, including the number of neutral civilians killed, the nature of the program (which critics have labelled as a "civilian assassination program,"[7]) the use of torture and other coercive methods, and the program being exploited for personal politics. Nevertheless, the program was very successful at suppressing Viet Cong political and revolutionary activities.[7] Public disclosure of the program led to significant criticism, including hearings by the US Congress, and the CIA was pressured to shut it down. A similar program, Plan F-6, continued under the government of South Vietnam.

>>14358774
>The Challenge, Andrew Lambert.
About the war of 1812, specifically the naval war and economic war.
>The British Way of War, Andrew Lambert. Ostensibly a biography of Sir Julian Corbett, but deals a lot with the pre-WW1 debates about national strategy in Great Britain.
>Thunder on the Danube (3 vols), John H. Gill
About the war of the war of the 5th coalition. One of the best Napoleonic campaign histories I've read.
>England in the Seven Years War: A Study in Combined Strategy (2 vols), Sir Julian S. Corbett
Title says it all, its main focus is in examining the war from a lessons learned perspective rather than a purely historical one.
>Some Principles of Maritime Strategy, Sir Julian S. Corbett
This is really a doctrinal primer from 1907, but it's very eye opening if you have any interest in historical seapower. Makes it far easier to understand the why's of many decisions at sea.
>The Roman War of Antiochus the Great, John D. Grainger
A detailed study of the conflict between Rome and the Seleucids
>Antigonus the One Eyed and the Creation of the Hellenistic State, Richard Billows
One half is a biography of Antigonus and the other half is an examination of how the Hellenistic states developed post-Alexander
>The End of the Bronze Age, Robert Drews
This is a really interesting book regarding the Bronze Age collapse, Drews argues that their was no great migration and that the sea peoples etc, were just the normal dwellers around the fringes of society who'd learnt how to destroy chariot armies and just wanted to kill, burn and maim.

>>14360815
Levy's "Conquistador" is has a fair amount of issues, I remember I read the first 10 pages or so and already noticed multiple major errors per page.

>when it was the tribes oppressed by the Mexica for years that took an opportunity to wreck vengeance on them.


This is a misconception.

There were no "tribes": Mesoamerican had urbanized state societies with cities and formal governments for thousands of years by this point. Basically every society the Aztec bothered to conquer or interact with were city-states, kingdoms., and empires;

Secondly, while the Mexica of Tenochtitlan were warmongering expansionists, they were hands off with the places they actually conquered, generally speaking. This is true of most large Mesoamerican empires, but the Aztec did things like installing rulers on conquered subjects etc less then other large Mesoamerican states: They basically just demanded taxes of economic goods, military service, and that roads not be blocked alongside a few other basic obligations, with subjects keeping their, laws, customs, etc. Sacrifices was something everybody did, and were mostly captured enemy soldiers from wars.

The reason Cortes got allies is that this hands off system enabled subject states to both act independently and have their own political ambitions, so you regularly had subjects seceding and launching coups opportunistically:

State X allying or pledging themselves as a subject to state Y (since subjects got left alone anyways) to take out their existing captial or political rivals, so then X could be in higher standing in Y's new kingdom, was a common method of political advancement. That's pretty much why Cortes and other conquistadors got allies, andt he Aztec empire itself was founded this way: Cortes was basically being used.

See: https://pastebin.com/VqW97h93

>>14363214
Have you ever considered what a breakthrough it would be if they could figure out the exact relationship between Israel and the Canaanites/Phoenicians? We know that they interacted closely because they were from the same region and had similar alphabets/languages, and we know that the bible says that other tribes in the region had biblical lineages (Esau -> Edom, Ishmael -> North Arabian tribes).
However, there are lots of gaps in our knowledge about this because the Phoenicians got genocided by the Romans and have barely any records remaining. Currently, the scholarly consensus is that the Israelites did not actually "wage war" against the Canaanites, but instead just sort of split off from the rest of them. Imagine if we could find the Phoenician account of all this stuff, it would shed so much light on everything. I think I read somewhere that a Greek author claimed an earlier Phoenician author could trace the history of the god Yahweh, though some Googling didn't really turn anything up.

>>14354476
The problem people make in judging God's goodness is that they say "pain = bad" and that's as far as their depth goes into the subject. So if anyone ever got an ouchie before, then God is evil.

But pain is a natural human bodily reaction, and a cautionary sign that you are in trouble and should seek some kind of help. That's why fire burns, because you got too close to it--if we couldn't feel pain, like some kind of leper, then we would go to sleep on a bed of coals and wake up dead after being immolated in fire that we could not sense.

In the same way Christians spurn lust, and wrath, and envy, they should want to spurn pain--not the pain itself, but their reaction to it. Christians cannot control if they feel lustful towards someone, or if they feel angry, or envious... but they can control their actions and reactions to those feelings. That's free will--what separates man from the soulless beasts that act only on instinct.

Even Jesus had his moment on the cross where he asked God why he had forsaken him, but he didn't let the pain undo him and cause him to damn God or cause him to lose his belief. He endured his pain, and he even comforted the thief who asked for forgiveness of his sins. And Jesus' last words before his death were to God, commending his spirit to Him and to Heaven. He survived the pain, his soul persisted.

The greatest mistake people make about this subject is to say that all those with disabilities or defects (or other poor life situations) are "suffering". And more often than not if you ask these people if they're happy... if they enjoy their life... if they find comfort in things around them, they'll tell you they do. It is only those who truly hate their own lives (often without reason) that believe those lesser than them must despise being alive. And I pity those people. And I pray for them.

>>14361597
Here have a "micro essay" I wrote on their rulers ought to act. 1/?

Irish literature, especially during the Ulster cycle, often serves as a type of kingship literature. That is, Irish literature seeks to inform the reader about what it means to be kingly, and the lengths a ruler must go through to maintain his standing as a king. “The Destruction of Da Derga's Hostel” and “On the Race of Conaire Mór” both fit this mold, in that they describe the origins of King Conaire Mór, his rise to power, and how to behave as a sovereign ruler. When examined together, it becomes clear that these two different stories work in tandem by telling the audience how a king should behave by describing noble lineage, performing on the battle field and the feast, and maintaining honor by observing taboos and gift giving.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14361612
2/?

There are many ways in which the tales “Destruction” and “Race” show the reader how a king should be honorable. One example from “Destruction” describes the background and noble lineage of Conaire. The story goes into detail, describing how Conaire’s mother is the daughter of a high king of Ireland and an Irish mythological being. His father was a king in a long line of kings, which passed down to Conaire. Having such a noble and mythological background would give any king added legitimacy, honor, and gravitas. “Race” mirrors this sentiment, by mentioning the kingly lineage and mystical background of Conaire's family in the beginning.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14361613
3/?

Another way that these two tales show the reader how to be kingly is to have a mighty army. In “Race”, the question of succession is up for debate when Conaire’s father dies. Conaire’s mother sought out a large army full of great men to assist Conaire in asserting his claim to the kingship. The army was so great that the defending claimants to the throne simply fled, leaving all their possessions and their claims to the kingdom behind. Thus, having driven his enemies before him, Conaire has successfully upped his honor by wielding a large army to take something by force of arms. However, in “Destruction”, Conaire does not come to power by force of arms. Instead, he relies on prophecy that says he will be king and stands up for his right at the feast by invoking his noble lineage. On the surface, these two stories of ascension appear add odds with one another. Upon closer inspection, the early and medieval Irish believed how one conducted themselves in battle, and at the self-positioning at a feast was one of the most important parts of being kingly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14361618
4/?

Being fierce on the battlefield and in the feasting hall wasn’t the only way to show kingly nature. A king must also be mindful of his taboos, and to skillfully negotiate them. In the beginning of “Destruction”, Conaire receives a list of taboos he must not break for dishonor would befall him. One such taboo placed on Conaire is he is to not allow three reds go before him into red’s house. For the Irish, violation of taboos could and did lead to great men dying a humiliating, and undignified death. In total, Conaire has nine taboos, and throughout the story he breaks them, which ultimately leads to his head being cut off. This is reminiscent of Cú Chulainn, who has no choice but to break one of his taboos and is then doomed to die.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14361622
5/5

Conaire didn’t only have an obligation to himself by avoiding taboos, he also had to maintain power by being generous. In “Destruction” and “Race”, Conaire gives many gifts to include land, cloth, weapons, cattle, and swine. He attempts to bribe the three reds that would violate his taboo. The three reds do not accept, which insults his generosity. Irish kings stake their reputation and honor price partially based on remaining in the dominant position by giving gifts. In denying Conaire, the reds have effectively reduced his gravitas, and worth as a ruler.

These two stories allow us to get a glimpse of what the Irish thought it meant to be kingly in nature. While “Destruction” and “Race” are of two different literary styles, they each work towards informing the reader how Irish kings should behave. From having a glorious origin, being strong on and off the battlefield, maintaining honor through observing taboos, and being generous; Irish king’s honor and rule appeared constantly under threat. Stories such as these would help inspire rulers to behave in a kinglier manner.

What lowered a king's face/honorprice? King doing manual labor, going in public without a retinue, defaulting on oath or doing something dishonorable like being defeated in battle, or killed while fleeing.

So if someone were dishonored in some way, and they normally get 21 cows, you might owe them only 3. Payment of reduced price is a way to shame those who’ve lost honor.

In fact there's an 8th century Irish law stating: “Any filth that stains a person’s honor, there are three things that wash it away: soap and water and towel. The first is the soap: confession of the misdeed before everyone and a promise not to do it again. The water, next, payment for
whatever perish through his misdeeds. The towel, penance for the misdeed by judgement."

>>14361655
How honor determined?
>status (all have it, but matter most for nobles)
>gender (mostly male)
>degree of independence (e.g. children, servants, etc.)

The Celts were aggressively competitive. People were constantly challenged in public, where your honor was continually assessed and revised since every single occasion is a venue for loss or gain. Performance on the battlefield to raise your honor is a given, but so is at the feast. Holding a feast by itself is an exercise of power, but that's not all to it. The feast is a very public occasion where you get to boast about your deeds, show off how close you sit to a honorable person, give gifts (which would subordinate yourself to someone) and get gifts (someone subordinating you) in front of everyone. Then there's the curadmír or "champions portion" where only the warrior acknowledged by all to be the strongest would get (and would often cause fights).

>>14361693
Warrior culture also included a key concept known as Geis, or taboos. These can be weird things that make no sense, but the warrior CANNOT break or they'll lose honor AND in the heroes cases, they'll be able to be killed. These taboos could be self-imposed, divine instructions, handed down by fathers and relatives and to break one means a loss of honor.

For example, Cú Chulainn was a hero who had two taboos: first was that Cú Chulainn must take and eat any food offered to him by a woman; the second was that he could not eat dog meat in any form. Can you see where this is going??? He is ultimately offered dog meat by a woman, and to deny either of them would lead to his doom, which it did.

As for the non-mythical, a taboo could be not shirk your duty on the battlefield. For a king it could be to have the right to the first night with any marriageable woman and the right to sleep with the wife of anyone who hosted him (this is attested though).

Toilets =/= indoor plumbing. There's two ways this was done without plumbing. Either you have a pot in the toilet that servants would have to take out and clean, or you would have the toilet facing an exterior wall, so it would dump outside of the building:
>The toilets of a castle were usually built into the walls so that they projected out on corbels and any waste fell below and into the castle moat. Even better, waste went directly into a river as is the case of the latrines of one of the large stone halls at Chepstow Castle in Wales, built from the 11th century CE. Some castles, such as the 11th-century CE Corfe Castle in Dorset, England had latrine shafts emptying directly in the courtyard or bailey while still others hung conveniently over a cliff face, as at Peveril Castle in Derbyshire, England, built in 1176-1777 CE.
https://www.worldhistory.org/article/1239/toilets-in-a-medieval-castle/#:~:text=The%20medieval%20toilet%20or%20latrine%2C%20then%20called%20a,the%20latrines%20which%20protrude%20from%20their%20exterior%20walls.

>>14365310
KMT started out with right-wings (pro-business, pro-Japanese wing) and a socialist wing (Commies) under Sun Yet-sun. Then the right wings under Chiang purged the commies out, who rallied under Mao.

The German post-WW1 needed allies and markets for its arms industry as well as raw materials since the France-British-Americans-Russians shut it out of virtually every colonial market. The KMT needed European weapons, aid, tech, everything. They cooperated. Chiang's son (Chiang Wei-kuo) even served in the German army which highlighted how close both right-winged/nationalist governments were at the time. German aid ended when the Second Sino-Japanese War started heating up and the Japanese broke out of Manchuria in 1937.

The KMT and Chinese understood the Japanese to be their greatest foreign threat. The USSR contested the Pacific against Japan (seen as the dominant power in East Asia and a rivalry going back to the Russo-Japanese War). The USSR aided the KMT government, but really the leftist communist wing mostly. The US was interested in supporting the Nationalists as a counter balance to Japan, and the UK/France joined in post Pearl Harbor as solidarity with the Americans.

The other thing too is that the Germans and Japanese were allies of convenience, even if it seems strange that the Germans were aiding the Chinese over their allies the Japs. They distrusted each other and never really committed any joint operations since they stayed within their own respective spheres. Obviously the Japanese detested the German aid to the Chinese, but the Germans needed markets and raw materials.

>>14365013
If you don't have a writing system already made for you, pictographs make the most sense. creating a alphabet to represent your language and (most importantly) getting everyone to agree to your characters and system is much harder.

It's much easier to get people to agree picture of fish means fish, then picture of fish represents the sound of the word fish.

One hundred fifty are besieged by five thousand;
Not only the provisions but the ammunition is all gone.
Thirty-two men hear the news and hurry to the scene.
The heavy strokes of their sabers lead them into the fortress, through the ranks of the enemy to see
The commander of the fortress wet with blood,
And his men reeling against the walls with exhaustion but with swords in hand.
Now comes the dauntless South Carolinian,
Knowing that if he does not answer duty's call, disgrace and shame will be his.
Returning he rides into the siege on a white charger,
Salutes the besieged with a smile, and says, "We die together."
They bind up their wounds and fight in higher spirits.
Speak not of the bravery of Chang Hsun at Suiyang, for here the one hundred and eighty-two corpses were laid; not one surrendered.
The people of the twenty-four states get inspiration thereby,
And learn for the first time that unanimous cooperation is superior to geographical advantage.
Why should they be mourned? For the dauntless, it is not a pain but a pleasure to cover an obstruction miles long.
Lo! the mouth of the river once occupied by the enemy is in the possession of the T' ang!
Now I am on a journey, far away from my home across the ocean.
I have come to San Antonio, where there are bushes of the graceful oleander.
And, as in a dream, I wonder if this is the very spot where that dreadful bloodshed took place in years gone by.
You do not see Chang Hsun, Hsu Yuan, and Nan Chiyun (David Crockett, Bowie, and Bonham)
But their fame, like the blossom's fragrance, is still in the air.
The custom of the West does not necessarily condemn surrender.
Why? We have never heard of a commander destroyed,
But here in the state of Texas, we see one (Travis).
In spirit there is not a distinction between East and West.
You need not wonder, then, if I drink a toast to your memory!
I have brought a well-polished stone from Japan,
And commemorate your heroic deeds with this humble inscription.

志賀重昂

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14364390
The Joseon surrendered and gave up the competition over control of Jianzhou Jurchens north of the Yalu and Tumen rivers, after Mentemu capitulated to the Ming.

after Mentemu's capitulation, Joseon Korean officials literally referred to the Jianzhou Jurchen territories north of the Yalu and Tumen rivers as part of Sanggok (the superior country, aka Ming China), and Ming China and Joseon delimitated their official borders as the yalu and tumen rivers.

There were some Jurchen lands south of the Tumen and yalu rivers on the Korean peninsula in Hamgyong province today. Koreans had to doctor earlier records and maps to claim they belonged to Goryeo during the Jin and Yuan dynasties (When they were in fact under Jurchen Jin control and part of Jurchen lands in the Yuan) in order to get Ming to agree to the border.

The only person who could claim Jianzhou Jurchens were under Joseon rule is a delusional Korean nationalist.

The Ming literally ruled the entire Jilin region as the Nurgan regional military commission in the Yongle reign and literally created the Jianzhou Juchen guard (weisuo) and Korea didn't use the wei suo guard system.

The Ming appointed the generals like Li Chengliang who managed the Jianzhou Jurchen guard.

>Writing "G-d" instead of God is a fairly recent custom in America. Many believe this to be a sign of respect, and the custom comes from an interpretation of the commandment in Deuteronomy 12:3-4 regarding the destruction of pagan altars. According to the medieval commentator, Rashi, we should not erase or destroy God’s name and should avoid writing it. In a Responsa (legal opinion) by the Central Conference of American Rabbis, the primary prohibition against erasure of the name God applies to the sacred names in a written text of Torah. With the advent of computers and the internet, rabbinic authorities have debated whether or not this applies to what is typed on a computer or read on a screen. Most have concurred that it does not apply.

>The bulk of Jewish legal opinion agrees that the law applies only to the written name of God when written in Hebrew and not when written in other languages. Reform Jewish practice reflects this opinion. Some Jews will avoid discarding paper or books in which God’s name appears in Hebrew. Rather than being thrown out or destroyed, they may be stored in a genizah (a storage place) and buried in a Jewish cemetery.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14364345
Several factors
1) Unlike Gallic Gallia, Switzerland, and bits of Austria, there's no large population centers in Germania. Archaeological and Primary sources attest to this. Meaning there's not much industry going on with these people beyond basic blacksmithing.
2) What armor & s we do find in Ancient Germania is often Celtic/Roman style, meaning that they most likely imported it. Hell in fact most of their swords look very Celtic, so we can assume they import those.

And finally/most importantly
3) Similar to the Gauls, your average Germanic warrior was not able to afford armor and mostly relied on shields for protection, a helmet if he is able to afford one. Only wealthier warriors and nobles swaggered around in armor.

To more sophisticated civilizations who can afford to armor even their mainline troops, they would appear to be underequipped.

>Harrison
Modernized the navy, implemented some of the first environmental protections, and was a zealous economic protectionist (an idea I'm quite partial to).

Kennedy being a good president lies moreso on his rhetoric and aesthetic image rather than any actual policy that he implemented. He was an outstanding orator and the posterboy of an antiquated American idealism that collapsed during the civil rights movement. Also, to his credit, he was arguably the last president besides Trump to criticize the military industrial complex and various three letter agencies that had overstepped their boundaries to assault the liberties of the American people.

I'm ambivalent to Wilson due to detesting his foreign policy. Cleveland was a big business shill who served as a bulwark against the progressive, nationally-minded Republicans. Coolidge had a solid immigration policy, but his laissez-faire stance on economic & social issues within the context of the times is something I'm diametrically opposed to. Nixon & Ford were unimaginative heads of state that failed to restore the dignity of the American Republic after the chaos engendered by the previous decade. Reagan was a bible-thumping neoliberal who spearheaded US decline, delayed slightly by the HW administration and the end of the cold war.

posts.name: Anonymous

>Modernized the navy
Harrison just continued the naval reform and construction Arthur, but especially Cleveland implemented.
>implemented some of the first environmental protections
Fair enough, but they were meager in comparison to Roosevelt and Wilson.
>and was a zealous economic protectionist (an idea I'm quite partial to).
A general level of protectionism is admirable, but Harrison's tariff rates were too high and slowed and then ultimately crashed the economy.
>moreso on his rhetoric and aesthetic image rather than any actual policy that he implemented
Yeah, I kinda figured. People like the idea and image of Kennedy more than they actually like any of his policies or successes, because he didn't exactly implement or have very many. And I don't think being a good orator necessarily makes you a good president. Both Harrison's, Pierce, Garfield, Andrew Johnson (whom I like) were also all skilled orators, but not considered by most people to be good presidents.
>Cleveland was a big business shill who served as a bulwark against the progressive, nationally-minded Republicans
No he wasn't. He implemented some of the first limitations on corrupt business practices, where the GOP were smitten with some of these guys, typically on Wall Street and the railroad industry.
>but his laissez-faire stance on economic
This is more conjecture than reality. Libertarians co-opted Coolidge, claiming that he's their guy, but his economics were squarely Hamiltonian. He was just as much of a protectionist as Harrison and most Republicans before him and expanded infrastructure spending, especially vis-a-vis roads and dams.
>& social issues
He was no different on social matters than most Republicans of the day.

>>14355895

Gothic architecture has long fallen out of style due to its prohibitive costs, long construction times, safety concerns about their weight, and reliance on materials such as certain types of stone and glass that are difficult and expensive to source, especially compared to concrete. Not to mention that all that the style greatly restricts the number of uses the building in question has. For instance, you can't really safely put a helipad on a building built in the Gothic style.

In addition, the structural limitations that necessitated the development of the Gothic style have long since been rendered redundant by the advent of concrete and steel beams (unmelted by jet fuel).
